text: From James, a slave of God and the Lord Jesus Christ, to the twelve tribes dispersed abroad. Greetings!
speaker: Narrator

text: My brothers and sisters, consider it nothing but joy when you fall into all sorts of trials,
speaker: Narrator

text: because you know that the testing of your faith produces endurance.
speaker: Narrator

text: And let endurance have its perfect effect, so that you will be perfect and complete, not deficient in anything.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if anyone is deficient in wisdom, he should ask God, who gives to all generously and without reprimand, and it will be given to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he must ask in faith without doubting, for the one who doubts is like a wave of the sea, blown and tossed around by the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: For that person must not suppose that he will receive anything from the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text: since he is a double-minded individual, unstable in all his ways.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the believer of humble means should take pride in his high position.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the rich person’s pride should be in his humiliation, because he will pass away like a wildflower in the meadow.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the sun rises with its heat and dries up the meadow; the petal of the flower falls off and its beauty is lost forever. So also the rich person in the midst of his pursuits will wither away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Happy is the one who endures testing, because when he has proven to be genuine, he will receive the crown of life that God promised to those who love him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let no one say when he is tempted, “I am tempted by God,” for God cannot be tempted by evil, and he himself tempts no one.
speaker: Narrator

text: But each one is tempted when he is lured and enticed by his own desires.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then when desire conceives, it gives birth to sin, and when sin is full grown, it gives birth to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not be led astray, my dear brothers and sisters.
speaker: Narrator

text: All generous giving and every perfect gift is from above, coming down from the Father of lights, with whom there is no variation or the slightest hint of change.
speaker: Narrator

text: By his sovereign plan he gave us birth through the message of truth, that we would be a kind of firstfruits of all he created.
speaker: Narrator

text: Understand this, my dear brothers and sisters! Let every person be quick to listen, slow to speak, slow to anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: For human anger does not accomplish God’s righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: So put away all filth and evil excess and humbly welcome the message implanted within you, which is able to save your souls.
speaker: Narrator

text: But be sure you live out the message and do not merely listen to it and so deceive yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if someone merely listens to the message and does not live it out, he is like someone who gazes at his own face in a mirror.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he gazes at himself and then goes out and immediately forgets what sort of person he was.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the one who peers into the perfect law of liberty and fixes his attention there, and does not become a forgetful listener but one who lives it out—he will be blessed in what he does.
speaker: Narrator

text: If someone thinks he is religious yet does not bridle his tongue, and so deceives his heart, his religion is futile.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pure and undefiled religion before God the Father is this: to care for orphans and widows in their adversity and to keep oneself unstained by the world.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brothers and sisters, do not show prejudice if you possess faith in our glorious Lord Jesus Christ.
speaker: Narrator

text: For if someone comes into your assembly wearing a gold ring and fine clothing, and a poor person enters in filthy clothes,
speaker: Narrator

text: do you pay attention to the one who is finely dressed and say, “You sit here in a good place,” and to the poor person, “You stand over there,” or “Sit on the floor”?
speaker: Narrator

text: If so, have you not made distinctions among yourselves and become judges with evil motives?
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen, my dear brothers and sisters! Did not God choose the poor in the world to be rich in faith and heirs of the kingdom that he promised to those who love him?
speaker: Narrator

text: But you have dishonored the poor! Are not the rich oppressing you and dragging you into the courts?
speaker: Narrator

text: Do they not blaspheme the good name of the one you belong to?
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you fulfill the royal law as expressed in this scripture, “You shall love your neighbor as yourself,” you are doing well.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you show prejudice, you are committing sin and are convicted by the law as violators.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the one who obeys the whole law but fails in one point has become guilty of all of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he who said, “Do not commit adultery,” also said, “Do not murder.” Now if you do not commit adultery but do commit murder, you have become a violator of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Speak and act as those who will be judged by a law that gives freedom.
speaker: Narrator

text: For judgment is merciless for the one who has shown no mercy. But mercy triumphs over judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: What good is it, my brothers and sisters, if someone claims to have faith but does not have works? Can this kind of faith save him?
speaker: Narrator

text: If a brother or sister is poorly clothed and lacks daily food,
speaker: Narrator

text: and one of you says to them, “Go in peace, keep warm and eat well,” but you do not give them what the body needs, what good is it?
speaker: Narrator

text: So also faith, if it does not have works, is dead being by itself.
speaker: Narrator

text: But someone will say, “You have faith and I have works.” Show me your faith without works and I will show you faith by my works.
speaker: Narrator

text: You believe that God is one; well and good. Even the demons believe that—and tremble with fear.
speaker: Narrator

text: But would you like evidence, you empty fellow, that faith without works is useless?
speaker: Narrator

text: Was not Abraham our father justified by works when he offered Isaac his son on the altar?
speaker: Narrator

text: You see that his faith was working together with his works and his faith was perfected by works.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the scripture was fulfilled that says, “Now Abraham believed God and it was counted to him for righteousness,” and he was called God’s friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: You see that a person is justified by works and not by faith alone.
speaker: Narrator

text: And similarly, was not Rahab the prostitute also justified by works when she welcomed the messengers and sent them out by another way?
speaker: Narrator

text: For just as the body without the spirit is dead, so also faith without works is dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Not many of you should become teachers, my brothers and sisters, because you know that we will be judged more strictly.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we all stumble in many ways. If someone does not stumble in what he says, he is a perfect individual, able to control the entire body as well.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if we put bits into the mouths of horses to get them to obey us, then we guide their entire bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look at ships too: Though they are so large and driven by harsh winds, they are steered by a tiny rudder wherever the pilot’s inclination directs.
speaker: Narrator

text: So too the tongue is a small part of the body, yet it has great pretensions. Think how small a flame sets a huge forest ablaze.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the tongue is a fire! The tongue represents the world of wrongdoing among the parts of our bodies. It pollutes the entire body and sets fire to the course of human existence—and is set on fire by hell.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every kind of animal, bird, reptile, and sea creature is subdued and has been subdued by humankind.
speaker: Narrator

text: But no human being can subdue the tongue; it is a restless evil, full of deadly poison.
speaker: Narrator

text: With it we bless the Lord and Father, and with it we curse people made in God’s image.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the same mouth come blessing and cursing. These things should not be so, my brothers and sisters.
speaker: Narrator

text: A spring does not pour out fresh water and bitter water from the same opening, does it?
speaker: Narrator

text: Can a fig tree produce olives, my brothers and sisters, or a vine produce figs? Neither can a salt water spring produce fresh water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who is wise and understanding among you? By his good conduct he should show his works done in the gentleness that wisdom brings.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you have bitter jealousy and selfishness in your hearts, do not boast and tell lies against the truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Such wisdom does not come from above but is earthly, natural, demonic.
speaker: Narrator

text: For where there is jealousy and selfishness, there is disorder and every evil practice.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the wisdom from above is first pure, then peaceable, gentle, accommodating, full of mercy and good fruit, impartial, and not hypocritical.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the fruit that consists of righteousness is planted in peace among those who make peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Where do the conflicts and where do the quarrels among you come from? Is it not from this, from your passions that battle inside you?
speaker: Narrator

text: You desire and you do not have; you murder and envy and you cannot obtain; you quarrel and fight. You do not have because you do not ask;
speaker: Narrator

text: you ask and do not receive because you ask wrongly, so you can spend it on your passions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adulterers, do you not know that friendship with the world means hostility toward God? So whoever decides to be the world’s friend makes himself God’s enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Or do you think the scripture means nothing when it says, “The spirit that God caused to live within us has an envious yearning”?
speaker: Narrator

text: But he gives greater grace. Therefore it says, “God opposes the proud, but he gives grace to the humble.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So submit to God. But resist the devil and he will flee from you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Draw near to God and he will draw near to you. Cleanse your hands, you sinners, and make your hearts pure, you double-minded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Grieve, mourn, and weep. Turn your laughter into mourning and your joy into despair.
speaker: Narrator

text: Humble yourselves before the Lord and he will exalt you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not speak against one another, brothers and sisters. He who speaks against a fellow believer or judges a fellow believer speaks against the law and judges the law. But if you judge the law, you are not a doer of the law but its judge.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there is only one who is lawgiver and judge—the one who is able to save and destroy. On the other hand, who are you to judge your neighbor?
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, you who say, “Today or tomorrow we will go into this or that town and spend a year there and do business and make a profit.”
speaker: Narrator

text: You do not know about tomorrow. What is your life like? For you are a puff of smoke that appears for a short time and then vanishes.
speaker: Narrator

text: You ought to say instead, “If the Lord is willing, then we will live and do this or that.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But as it is, you boast about your arrogant plans. All such boasting is evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: So whoever knows what is good to do and does not do it is guilty of sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Come now, you rich! Weep and cry aloud over the miseries that are coming on you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your riches have rotted and your clothing has become moth-eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your gold and silver have rusted and their rust will be a witness against you. It will consume your flesh like fire. It is in the last days that you have hoarded treasure!
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, the pay you have held back from the workers who mowed your fields cries out against you, and the cries of the reapers have reached the ears of the Lord of Heaven’s Armies.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have lived indulgently and luxuriously on the earth. You have fattened your hearts in a day of slaughter.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have condemned and murdered the righteous person, although he does not resist you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So be patient, brothers and sisters, until the Lord’s return. Think of how the farmer waits for the precious fruit of the ground and is patient for it until it receives the early and late rains.
speaker: Narrator

text: You also be patient and strengthen your hearts, for the Lord’s return is near.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not grumble against one another, brothers and sisters, so that you may not be judged. See, the judge stands before the gates!
speaker: Narrator

text: As an example of suffering and patience, brothers and sisters, take the prophets who spoke in the Lord’s name.
speaker: Narrator

text: Think of how we regard as blessed those who have endured. You have heard of Job’s endurance and you have seen the Lord’s purpose, that the Lord is full of compassion and mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: And above all, my brothers and sisters, do not swear, either by heaven or by earth or by any other oath. But let your “Yes” be yes and your “No” be no, so that you may not fall into judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is anyone among you suffering? He should pray. Is anyone in good spirits? He should sing praises.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is anyone among you ill? He should summon the elders of the church, and they should pray for him and anoint him with olive oil in the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the prayer of faith will save the one who is sick and the Lord will raise him up—and if he has committed sins, he will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: So confess your sins to one another and pray for one another so that you may be healed. The prayer of a righteous person has great effectiveness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah was a human being like us, and he prayed earnestly that it would not rain and there was no rain on the land for three years and six months!
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he prayed again, and the sky gave rain and the land sprouted with a harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: My brothers and sisters, if anyone among you wanders from the truth and someone turns him back,
speaker: Narrator

text: he should know that the one who turns a sinner back from his wandering path will save that person’s soul from death and will cover a multitude of sins.
speaker: Narrator
